questions.content:
Scope

This Interactive Clinical Guideline (ICG) will help guide clinicians in selecting therapy for an adult with Helicobacter pylori infection who has not previously been treated. Several guidelines address the management of H. pylori. The recommendations in this ICG generally represent the recommendations from the Toronto guidelines.

If any alarm symptoms are present the patient should undergo upper endoscopy for further evaluation in addition to receiving treatment for H. pylori. Alarm symptoms include anemia, early satiety, unexplained weight loss, dysphagia, odynophagia, recurrent vomiting, a family history of gastrointestinal cancer, and previous esophagogastric malignancy.

Last updated 12/12/2016

Exclusions

This ICG is not appropriate for patients with any of the following exclusions:
  • Prior treatment for H. pylori
  • Age <18 years
  • Pregnant or breastfeeding
Required Tests

No test results other than an initial test that is positive for H. pylori infection are needed in order to complete this ICG.

questions.content:
Does the patient have risk factors for antibiotic resistance?

Risk factors include:
  • Metronidazole use in the last three months
  • Macrolide (eg, clarithromycin, azithromycin, or erythromycin) use in the last three months
  • Residence in an area where H. pylori resistance to clarithromycin is ≥15% or where eradication rates with triple therapy are ≤85%
In the United States, given the limited information on antimicrobial resistance rates, we generally assume clarithromycin resistance rates are ≥15% unless local data indicate otherwise.

questions.content:
Quadruple therapy with a PPI, bismuth, a tetracycline derivative, and metronidazole for 14 days is appropriate for this patient.

Patients should be informed that adherence to treatment is a critical factor in determining the success of eradication therapy. Because the regimen includes metronidazole, strict alcohol avoidance should be advised. Quadruple therapy can be administered by providing each agent individually or by providing a PPI plus a combination pill (Pylera), which combines bismuth and the two antibiotics into a single pill. Combination pills may improve adherence, but may also be more expensive. Following treatment, testing should be performed to confirm eradication.

Choose one proton pump inhibitor (PPI) from the following options (discontinue prior PPI dosing, if patient has been taking a PPI).

If esomeprazole is chosen, it can either be given as 40 mg once daily or 20 mg twice daily. The Toronto Consensus guideline considers 20 mg twice daily to be the standard dose for the treatment of H. pylori.

questions.content:
Confirmation of H. pylori eradication by stool or breath test following treatment is recommended. For patients who are scheduled for an upper endoscopy following treatment, eradication can be determined at the time of endoscopy. For other patients, an H. pylori test should be done at least 4 weeks after treatment is completed. Patients should not take a PPI or bismuth for 4 weeks prior to confirmation testing.

Note, in patients with peptic ulcers, antisecretory therapy with a PPI may need to be continued for more than 4 weeks (thus delaying eradication confirmation). For patients with complicated duodenal ulcers (eg, ulcers with bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, ulcer penetration, or perforation), the PPI should be continued for 4 to 8 weeks. For patients with gastric ulcers, the PPI should be continued for 8 to 12 weeks.
